about.title: From systems & networks to Salesforce development
about.subtitle: A technical profile with a strong IT infrastructure background, now fully focused on Salesforce and cloud consulting.
about.paragraph1: I started my career on the infrastructure side as a Junior Systems & Network Administrator. I supported users, managed Windows environments, monitored networks and handled security incidents. This hands‑on experience taught me how real‑world systems behave, how teams collaborate under pressure, and why robust foundations matter.
about.paragraph2: Today I specialise in Salesforce development and administration. After completing the Salesforce Developer path at OpenClassrooms and working on Apex, Flows and CI/CD with Salesforce CLI, I now help organisations automate processes, improve data quality and build secure, maintainable solutions.
about.paragraph3: I work best in environments where autonomy, transparency and continuous learning are valued. My goal for 2025 is to operate as an international freelance Salesforce Developer & Consultant, collaborating with distributed teams and customers across Europe, Cyprus and Asia‑Pacific.

items.name: Backend Apex for iDEM Connect
items.context: iDEM Connect, a global ISP (1.8 B€ revenue, 3,950 employees), needed a backend to manage contracts, orders and account status in Salesforce.
items.role: Implemented Apex triggers (OrderTrigger) and handlers to enforce business rules: prevented activating orders without line items; automatically set Account.Active__c to true on order insert and false when the last order is deleted; scheduled a batch and scheduler to create call tasks for accounts without recent orders; created configuration classes and test factories; documented design and wrote comprehensive unit tests achieving 90% coverage.
items.impact: Ensured data integrity and automated recurring tasks, resulting in consistent account status management and proactive customer follow‑up; delivered maintainable code with strong test coverage and technical documentation.

items.name: Deploy Salesforce Application for Legarant‑AXG
items.context: Insurance company Legarant, following its acquisition of AXG, needed to migrate AXG’s CRM data into Legarant’s Salesforce org and deploy a mobile application for insurance agents.
items.role: As a senior developer, I led the integration project: configured Heroku environments (staging and production) with Postgres, Heroku Connect and logging add‑ons; built a Node.js backend (server.js) and web interface hosted on Heroku to expose REST endpoints for the mobile app; created a Salesforce Connected App and permission sets; implemented Apex REST services and a Postman collection using OAuth 2.0; documented environment variables, deployment steps and manual actions; and coordinated the deployment pipeline from sandbox to production.
items.impact: Delivered a secure integration platform that synchronised AXG data into Legarant’s Salesforce via Heroku Connect and supported a mobile application for agents. Provided comprehensive documentation and automated tests, enabling seamless deployment and efficient adoption by the business.

items.name: Salesforce Solution for Tours For Life
items.context: Travel agency Tours For Life needed a Salesforce solution to manage prospects, travellers, trips and a bus fleet while increasing revenue.
items.role: Analysed requirements, designed a data model with custom objects (Prospect, Voyageur, Voyage, Voyages achetés, Flotte de bus), set up Person Accounts, created Flows for conversions, email notifications and seat decrement, configured roles and sharing rules, built reports and dashboards, and trained users.
items.impact: Simplified trip management and boosted revenue by automating lead conversion and booking; improved data accuracy and visibility; enabled directors to manage the bus fleet and monitor sales.

items.name: Digit Learning App Update
items.context: Online education company Digit Learning needed to streamline its Salesforce application for managing students, mentors and courses.
items.role: Audited the existing Salesforce org, redesigned the data model and implemented Flows, validation rules and automations to assign mentors, register students and track alumni.
items.impact: Reduced the time per student from over 30 minutes to around 5 minutes for mentor assignment and course registration; cut follow‑up time for alumni from over 15 minutes to 10 minutes; improved data accuracy and user satisfaction.

items.name: Backend Optimisation for FASHA
items.context: Multinational fashion retailer FASHA experienced slow batch jobs, application freezes and disorganised Apex code in its Salesforce CRM.
items.role: Reviewed and refactored the Apex backend: moved SOQL and DML out of loops, modularised classes, applied consistent naming conventions and optimised the revenue batch processes.
items.impact: Batch jobs processed significantly faster, user interactions no longer froze during account and order updates, and the codebase became maintainable with strong test coverage.

items.name: Lightning App for Avenir Télécom
items.context: Avenir Télécom’s southern sales division required a tailored Salesforce Lightning application to increase productivity and provide a 360° customer view.

items.name: Visualforce to Lightning Migration

digit-learning-app-update.title: Digit Learning – Salesforce App Improvement
digit-learning-app-update.summary: Refactoring Digit Learning’s Salesforce environment to automate mentor assignment, course enrolment, status updates and reporting, reducing manual work by more than 80 %.

badges.label: Automation flows
badges.description: Mentor assignment, status updates, seat decrement

problems: The data model only allowed one course per student, forcing duplication of records.
Student status had to be updated manually, taking around 15 minutes per student and leading to errors.
Sales reps manually decremented available seats when recording a purchase, a process that took over 30 minutes and caused 10 – 15 % data errors.
Managers lacked metrics and dashboards to monitor course capacity, mentor workloads and conversion rates.
objectives: Design a data model that supports multiple course purchases per student without duplication.
Automate status updates based on course purchase and end dates.
Automate the decrement of available seats when a course is purchased.
Provide actionable reports and dashboards to track training capacities, conversion rates and mentor performance.
Save time for the sales team and improve data quality.
methodology: Conducted interviews with key users and audited the existing Salesforce org to identify pain points.
Created a new custom object to store course purchases and restructured relationships between students and courses to allow multiple enrolments.
Built declarative flows to assign mentors automatically, update student status when a course is purchased or completed, and decrement available seats without manual intervention.
Implemented validation rules to enforce mandatory fields such as phone numbers and ensure data integrity.
Configured reports and dashboards: students by mentor and status, courses by type with remaining seats, and conversion rate comparisons before and after automation.
Deployed the changes through a sandbox using Workbench and trained users to adopt the new processes.
results: Mentor assignment and course enrolment time reduced from over 30 minutes to about 5 minutes per student.
Status updates automated, saving approximately 15 minutes per student.
Seat management automated, reducing errors by an estimated 10 – 15 % and freeing the team from manual updates.
New dashboards provide real‑time insight into course capacity and conversions, enabling informed decisions for growth.
Overall efficiency gains allow staff to focus on coaching and business development rather than manual data entry.
jury: The jury highlighted the thorough understanding of user needs, the relevance of the proposed automations and the clarity of the delivered dashboards.
They commended the significant time savings achieved and the improved data quality.

backend-optimisation-fasha.title: Backend Optimisation for FASHA
backend-optimisation-fasha.summary: Refactoring triggers, batch Apex performance, reliable Net Amount calculations and code aligned with best practices to stabilise the CRM and accelerate weekly revenue updates.
problems: The UpdateAccountCA trigger failed on accounts with more than 100 orders.
Net Amount was correct in the UI but incorrect during imports via Data Loader.
The weekly revenue batch was too slow.
Disorganised code – inconsistent naming conventions, overly long classes and non‑compliant tests.
objectives: Optimise the backend: move SOQL/DML out of triggers and avoid DML inside loops.
Accelerate the weekly revenue update batch.
Refactor the architecture (services, utilities, controllers).
Make Net Amount calculation reliable, including during mass imports.

methodology.title: Audit & refactoring
methodology.description: Apply naming conventions, break up classes and clean up the codebase.

methodology.title: Slim triggers
methodology.description: Remove SOQL and DML from triggers and delegate logic to service classes.

methodology.title: Reliable Net Amount
methodology.description: Handle mass imports correctly so that Net Amount is calculated accurately.

methodology.title: Performant batch
methodology.description: Optimise and harden the weekly batch job to process large volumes efficiently.

methodology.title: Solid unit tests
methodology.description: Write structured tests with assertions aligned to best practices.

methodology.title: Team views
methodology.description: Implement controller logic to provide views per salesperson.

results: Stabilised the application even on large volumes.
Significantly accelerated the weekly batch.
Refactored code that is clear and maintainable.
Reliable Net Amount calculation, including during mass imports.
jury: Good understanding of the mission, clear and relevant solutions, excellent oral presentation. Congratulations on the work done.
Triggers free of DML/DB operations; logic moved to service classes.
Optimised SOQL with no DML or queries inside loops.
Unit tests compliant with good coverage.
